주소: Phra Borom Maha Ratchawang, Phra Nakhon, Bangkok 10200, Thailand
리뷰: This is a must visit for anyone in Bangkok. It's just an awe inspiring place to wander around and see the sights of the different temples and buildings, there's just so much to see. Do make sure you have read the dress code rules before going, in particular make sure you are wearing long pants no exceptions apart from children, you can buy a pair at the entrance for 200 baht but they are not very comfortable! It can also get very hot and crowded so make sure you've packed lots of water and wear lots of sunscreen. Extremely beautiful temple! However it is very touristy, personally i prefer the less crowded places. But if you don't mind crowds and photos full of people you don't know, it's the perfect place. There are traditional Thai outfits that people are renting and wearing, which are very beautiful. It's crazy hot here. My friends and I showed up around 11, and it was packed. But it was cool checking out all the historic buildings in Thailand. Everyone was super friendly, and I even got to meet some people from Vietnam!  A must see. Some will say that it is very luxurious, wonderful, magical. Others will say eclectic. Anyway, it's a must visit. It is forbidden to wear shorts or a short skirt, but you can buy pants at the exit three times cheaper than at the entrance. A free umbrella and guided tour are available. Enjoy! Its a good place to visit if you havent been to any of the Asian castles of that type. It provides you with a huge contrast with e.g. European style castles. Good to visit once, but to me going back is hardly an option and also going here would not make much sense if you have been to a similar place before in Bangkok or other similar Asian cities. However, this castle cover it all if you havent been to any of those and you are selecting the one to go first time. The decoration and the shape of the buildings is very interesting, as well as large paintings over the whole walls. Overall a borderline 5 stars to me, mainly due to the contrast it provides compared to European architecture and culture

It's a great little park area where many locals and tourists come to relax. Plenty space for a picnic or exercise. Personally, it is my favourite spot to watch the sunset and boats cruising on the river. In the evening there is a chance to practise dancing with local people  and listen to the music . Can't wait to go back there. It's one of my favourite spots in Bangkok . This is one of the best places in Thailand around khosan road. It has no entrance and the place is amazing. Peaceful and beautiful park. You can sit for sometimes doing your things and thinking about the plan what to do in Thailand. Its really wonderful place. The fort has different weapons and it shows how they were kept the city in ancient times. And its very close to the river and it has a great view with that. I recommend this place to anyone stays around khosan road. Nice little fort along the riverside with the park. I had the chance to see it at night time but I must revisit during the daytime. It looks like it could be a very incredible view overlooking the river and the modernday bridge. A tranquil park. Which is a rarity in a manic place like bangkok.

Lots of benches and a cool breeze of the river provides a welcome break Small fort near Khao san road for a quick walk or a river view. Can click some good pictures with a beautiful backdrop of the river and bridge .

No entry fee.

이름: The Temple of the Emerald Buddha
주소: QF2V+M34, Na Phra Lan Rd, Khwaeng Phra Borom Maha Ratchawang, Khet Phra Nakhon, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon 10200, Thailand
리뷰:
A beautiful place with lots of gold. The actual Buddha is much smaller than expected, but still worth seeing. I particularly liked the artwork on the walls. There were fans in the building and it was much cooler than outside which was nice.

However it was SO busy when we went it, was almost too busy. There were people everywhere pushing from all directions. It was also very hot.

Cool place, but make sure you GO EARLY. Id also recommend booking your tickets in advance online so you can beat some of the longgggg queues. Commonly known in English as the Temple of Emerald Buddha, the temple located within the grounds of the Grand Palace it is regarded as the most sacred Buddhist temple in Thailand and it enshrines the highly revered Buddha image meticulously carved from a single block of jade.
There are so many beautiful intricate details and ornaments but you should know its extremely crowded.
I didnt quite enjoy the experience itself because of the heat and crowds but its a must visit when in Bangkok.

Note Be aware youd need to wear long items of clothing covering shoulders and below the knees The site houses a historical Jade Buddha, though photography is unfortunately not permitted inside the temple itself. However, photos are allowed in the surrounding area. The grounds are clean, with clear signage, making it easy to navigate. The only downside is the somewhat high ticket price of 500 baht per adult. Other than that, theres little to complain about.

Pro
History and culture value
Clean
Clear sign

Cons
Tickets are expensive The temple is very holy and sacred. It is definitely an architectural treasure of Thailand. It worth the visit when you go to the Grand Palace. It is a must visit site.
Please buy the tickets online in advance to avoid queues. Admission fee for foreigners is 500 baht which includes the Grand palace and a couple of museums. This is a must see in Bangkok, although  the Emerald Buddha is very small its still a beautiful temple complex. Closes at 330 PM and its very crowded, people taking pics everywhere so its hard to move around as you have to wait to let them take their pic!

There are a lot of this little Forts painted in white around the inner city. Often surrounded with a beautiful park or garden. Nothing to see, nothing inside, just a nice place with some canons. Nice little area to walk around, well looked after. Was smaller than I thought though. Took us less than 5 mins to walk through. We saw a komodo dragonalligator looking creature having a swim. I enjoyed seeing this. Watch out for this beast.

주소: ชั้น บี1-บี2 สยามพารากอน 991 Rama I Rd, Khwaeng Pathum Wan, Pathum Wan, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon 10330, Thailand
리뷰:
I recently visited Sea Life Aquarium in Bangkok, and it was an absolutely wonderful experience for kids and families alike. The aquarium features stunning natural tanks filled with a diverse array of fish and marine life, making it a captivating environment for young explorers.

The interior design is beautifully arranged, enhancing the overall experience with vibrant colors and engaging displays. The glass boat ride was a highlight, allowing us to glide through underwater tunnels surrounded by majestic sea creaturesan unforgettable way to connect with the marine world.

Additionally, the 5D movie experience was thrilling, immersing us in an interactive adventure that was both entertaining and educational. Overall, Sea Life Aquarium offers a fantastic day out for families, combining fun with learning in a breathtaking setting. Highly recommended! very beautiful, many species of marine life, children really enjoy it.
The shark tunnel was the highlight of my visit. It felt like I was transported to a vast ocean when I walked through the transparent tunnel, surrounded by countless sharks of all sizes. The shimmering lights created a magical atmosphere, making me feel like I was swimming alongside these gigantic creatures SEA LIFE Bangkok Ocean World is an extraordinary and highly recommended destination. The wide range of marine life on display is both stunning and captivating. Each section of the aquarium is wellorganized, making it easy to navigate and explore the various aquatic species. I was particularly impressed by how seamless the transitions between the different sections were. Another highlight for me was the 4D show, which added a fun and immersive experience to the visit. Overall, its a great place to enjoy and learn about marine life in a beautifully structured environment. Visiting SEA LIFE Bangkok with my young daughter was an exceptional experience. This aquarium offers a captivating adventure for children and adults alike. The variety of marine life on display is both extensive and impressive, featuring everything from vibrant fish and graceful rays to majestic sharks and playful sea turtles.

The exhibits are thoughtfully designed to be both educational and engaging, with interactive elements that are perfect for young kids. My daughter was particularly enchanted by the mesmerizing underwater tunnel, which provides a panoramic view of marine life swimming all around. The handson activities and touch pools added an extra layer of excitement and learning for her.

The facility is wellmaintained, and the staff are friendly and knowledgeable, enhancing the overall experience. SEA LIFE Bangkok's commitment to conservation and education is evident throughout, making it not only a fun day out but also a valuable learning opportunity for children.

For families visiting Bangkok, SEA LIFE Bangkok is a highly recommended destination. It offers a delightful and enriching experience that will leave both children and parents with lasting memories. Sea Life Bangkok Aquarium is a mustvisit place! Although the ticket price is a bit high at around 2,500 Baht per person, it is definitely worth spending. The experience starts with a fantastic 20minute 3D show, complete with moving chairs that give you a reallife feeling.

After the show, you can explore the aquarium, which features an incredible variety of sea creatures. From sharks to stingrays, jellyfish to sea snakes, you can see it all up close. You can also enjoy popcorn and Coke, and there's even a free photo opportunity.

One tip I highly recommend buying your tickets in advance, as they dont accept cash at the entrance. It's best to purchase your tickets at least a day before your visit to avoid any hassle.

Overall, Sea Life Bangkok Aquarium offers an amazing and immersive experience for visitors of all ages.

It's an upscale open market for goodies and souvenirs. Good ambience, average food that you can get anywhere else in Bangkok. Worth a onetime visit though and easily accessible through express boat service on Chao Phraya river 500baht per person. Worth the money for us as tourist. Not sure about the citizen as not much people are queueing up except for tourist. Maybe it is considered pricey to them. 3 rounds only, maybe around 15mins20mins? I took free shuttle boat from Sathorn Pier. And prior that I took BTS to Saphan Taksin BTS Station. Around 5mins walking. No escalator or lift. Only flight of stairs. So travel light please. Boat is every 30mins. 4pm till 1130pm. Please spend some time here. We regret not spending much time due to the crankiness of our kid. But as for you, please spend at least 2 or 3 hours. Lots to see and try! Great place to eat beautiful food as there's plenty of restaurants
Clothing outlets, souvenir shops,
Boat cruises
Kids will enjoy Really nice place to visit. Price for the ferry wheel ride is a bit too much. It was 500 baht per person for just 15 minutes 3 rounds. But the experience is amazing.  It was a very enjoyable experience, though there wasn't an overwhelming amount to do. I'd recommend pairing it with another activity. It's a bit pricey but worth it overall. I'd visit again, but I'd prioritize other attractions in Bangkok.

리뷰:
I went here primarily for the Siam Amazing Waterpark and didn't expect this place to exist. It's a really nice space with replicas of some iconic Bangkok sites like the Giant Swing and Democracy Monument. There is an area called Chinatown with old Chinese inspired architecture. They also have a big food hall with dinosaur statues. It's sort of like a theme park for Bangkok. It was not very busy and felt a bit empty, so I'm not sure when the best time to come is. I visited on 28 Dec Thurs. I think this place has huge potential to be amazing. Obviously a lot of money and effort has been invested here and it looks great. I hope more people will visit more often to create the vibrant atmosphere it needs. Entry to this area is free, the ticket booth is for Siam Amazing Park. Super empty. I couldn't find any shop opened at all.

The cafeteria was pretty much dead too  only a food stall and a drink corner were opened.

Very sad to see a huge amount of investment spent to build a ghost town. Log Flume was by far the best ride and different to any I had been on before. However many rides in the amusement park were closed or not operational. However there was many short queue which was a bonus. The water park was a major let down. 23 of slides closed and not able to use, for the wave pool they didnt even turn on the wave machine and when it claims the title of largest in the world youd think they would actually use it? Pool was also filthy and hadnt been cleaned in a long time. Bangkok World, an ambitious project slated to become one of the city's premier entertainment and leisure destinations, promises a worldclass experience like no other. Nestled in the heart of the bustling metropolis, this upcoming development aims to redefine the city's skyline and captivate visitors with its grandeur and innovation.

Spanning a vast expanse of land, Bangkok World boasts an impressive array of attractions, including luxury hotels, upscale shopping malls, dazzling entertainment venues, and iconic landmarks. From highend boutiques to gourmet restaurants, there's something to cater to every taste and preference.

But what truly sets Bangkok World apart is its commitment to sustainability and environmental stewardship. With green spaces, ecofriendly architecture, and innovative energysaving initiatives, the development strives to harmonize with its surroundings while minimizing its ecological footprint.

As Bangkok's newest urban destination, Bangkok World holds the promise of endless possibilities and unforgettable experiences. Whether you're a discerning traveler, a savvy shopper, or simply seeking a taste of luxury and excitement, a visit to Bangkok World is sure to leave a lasting impression and create memories to cherish for a lifetime. very beautiful at night,clean, lot parking,must visit once

주소: 2 Lan Luang Rd, Khwaeng Wat Sommanat, Khet Pom Prap Sattru Phai, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon 10100, Thailand
리뷰:
As a person who loves history and a selfproclaimed 'old soul', I have great interest in historial museums because it takes me back in time. I've been meaning to visit King Prajadhipok Museum for quite sometime but laziness  and distance  and someone to go together always hinders me to check it out. Glad to have found someone to go there this time. 

The impression of the museum is very homey for me  for some reason. It's like an old threestorey mansion with deep history and finally the government decided to honor it to house the wonderful journey of life of King Prajadhipok Rama VII. Just an information, the museum was actually built for commercial purposes during King Chulalongkorn's reign and was under the Royal Treasury then Public Works Department before it was registered as a heritage site in modern times.

I am very impressed how the museum walked us through King Prajadhipok's life from childhood until his death at a very young age of 48. As I was browsing the details provided through the walkthrough, I felt so overwhelmed with emotions  happiness, sadness, suspense, intrigue. My brain is imaginative that's why I feel like I was watching a movie of King Prajadhipok's life  from childhood to adulthood, and how the fifth ? child instead became king.

Though his life was full of challenges since young  he was a sickly boy according to the provided historical information  I assumed he had a fulfilling and happy life with his wife  Queen Rambai Barni. As I was looking at their pictures  despite the troublesome days and many intrigues during his reign, it is evident that both of them tried to live a life of happiness. And I am glad to witness their life still at this time.

The museum is free as of October 2024. It is at a prime location and also near some interesting temples too. I highly recommend to those who'd like to have a glimpse and would like to learn a bit about Thailand's history to drop by. The museum is wellmaintained and hopefully will be continued to do so. I cannot express how much I appreciated my visit to King Prajadhipok Museum that I started reading more about Thailand's history and royalties until late night when I returned home. I enjoyed this museum. There was no fee to enter, you just need to fill up a visitor log. There's also free parking at the back if you have a motorcycle or a car. The museum was well laid out and properly curated. I learned so many things about the Siamese Kingdom, King Prahadjipok and his family and how the current government constitutional monarchy was formed.

We were the only tourists so we had the museum to ourselves then there was a group of highschool kids that caught up to us.

If you are looking for something to do to fill in a few hours of your day, I recommend visiting this museum. I had no idea this place existed, i was walking toward the Queens gallery and the museum is located on the adjacent street.
Free to enter, you must look all you belongings, you are only allowed to have you phone in the building, you are free to explore 3 floors on the life of the great uncle? of Thailands current king.
The firstonly? to abdicate the museum explores a really fascinating look at the life a Thai monarch who with 3 older legit brothers shouldn't have been king to begin with.
Im not Thai and went in expecting to be out in 20 minutes, i was there for 90 I love this museum.  See pictures and learn history of  King and Queen Rama VII. The Prajadhipok Museum in Thailand is a hidden gem that offers a deep dive into the fascinating history of King Prajadhipok Rama VII and Thailand's transition to constitutional monarchy. The museum is beautifully curated with wellpreserved artifacts, photographs, and personal items that give visitors an intimate look at the life and reign of the king. The exhibits are informative, wellorganized, and engaging, making it a perfect stop for history lovers. The building itself is a stunning piece of architecture, and the peaceful atmosphere adds to the overall experience. Highly recommended for anyone interested in Thailand's rich history!

리뷰:
Talat Noi is one of the most underrated districts of Bangkok, yet it is its heart and soul.

We did it on a scooter motorcycle, stopping from time to time to take pictures, grab a coffee, or admire a detail, and it was just fine this way. Not that I recommend everyone use a motorcycle in those narrow and mazelike streets unless you're a seasoned and very careful rider.

Hipster as it is, this ancient neighborhood is a great place to hang out, try coffee curiosities, and mingle with fellow artdriven tourists along with locals. As a chocolate expert I can really say its an amazing place to visit and try hot and cold drink chocolate. They have many varieties from different regions which I really appreciate, of course as usual I take always the 100 one because so you can feel the quality of chocolate. Was nice to meet you and may stay in contact if you need help in developing chocolate, the guy who worked there has my number. If you want check IG Taucherlichocolate and also helped some chocolate brands in Thailand Three hours of walking and exploring at Talat Noi, after reading some introduction on this old district in BKK. The street art is not the only drawing factor, the different characters of the cafes was the reason why I was drawn to it. Besides there are many traditional food at very reasonable prices tug at different corners.. hopefully the prices wont triple with more locals and tourists checking out the area. One of the oldest area of bangkok. Very clean  well maintained. The street arts are very beautiful. Perfect place to take good photos. Please check the videos. Nice area in Bangkok to go see. A lot of street art and a lot of motor parts all over the neighbourhood. Many narrow and old alleys to walk around and theres also quite a few restaurants and coffeetea shops. Go here and expect to spend 4560 mins to explore the area thoroughly. Definitely go here if you are a street artist yourself

주소: Lak Muang Rd, Khwaeng Phra Borom Maha Ratchawang, Khet Phra Nakhon, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon 10200, Thailand
리뷰:
It is one of the key spots in Bangkok where people can make merit and pray for success in business.
The architecture is really nice here.
I also like the way they make the praying more sustainable by asking people not to burn the incense and candles. Just reuse it as part of the ritual. Reduce pollution and use of materials.  Bangkok has so many crafted beautiful architecture, and this is one of them. Locals and buddhist travelers come here to make offering to the shrine. It is conveniently located across the street to the Grand Palace and next to the  Ministry of Defence. You can buy some followers, make offering and do prayers at the side gate entrance building, spire column or the ground floor tent. They also have smll charming plant and flower garden on the side of the Grand Palace direction. I highly recommend  visit. Stunning place!!!  The Pillar that protects the Country of Thailand located near to the Thai Grand Palace, Wat Phra Kaew and Wat Pho...rarely see tourists go there as it is well known among Thais local. Thai locals believe to visit and pay respect at Bkk City Pillar Shrine at least once a year for luck and prosperity especially after New Years hoilday.  You can buy a flower set few colorful ropes to tie the pillar in the inside for approximately 60 Thai Baht. Instructions will be provided. A very nice highly trafficked site, Buddhist and secular mix.  The city pillars are covered.  The artwork is the gorgeous Thai style.  Dress appropriately.  And yes, worth a visit even after you see the other superb tourist sites next door.

주소: PGR5+4W6, Yaowarat Rd, Khwaeng Samphanthawong, Khet Samphanthawong, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon 10100, Thailand
리뷰:
Chinatown is my personal favorite spot in Bangkok at night. During the day, it can feel quite empty, but at night, Chinatown comes alive in all its glory. Its like a fairy tale for extroverts!

Theres something magical about sitting on the street with a beer, soaking in the vibrant atmosphere and the bustling life around you. It truly feels like a different world within Bangkok. I wish I had visited earlier in my trip, but I highly recommend experiencing it! Bangkok Chinatown is a vibrant and bustling area that offers an authentic Chinese cultural experience right in the heart of Bangkok. The streets are filled with colorful shops, street vendors, and delicious food stalls that serve some of the best street food I've ever had. From dim sum to noodles, there's something for everyone!
The atmosphere is lively, especially at night when the neon lights come on, making it an excellent spot for evening strolls and photography. Many traditional shops and markets also sell everything from herbs to souvenirs.

Highly recommend visiting Chinatown, especially if you love exploring diverse cultures and trying new foods! Lively  busy atmosphere out here  youll definitely enjoy the sight of foods! There are many options for you to try depending on your taste bud. Highly recommend to visit during night time. Walking through Bangkoks Chinatown Yaowarat at around 7 PM was an experience like no other! The entire street was alive with energy, vibrant lights, and the aroma of street food filling the air. Everywhere I looked, there were bustling food stalls offering a variety of local delicacies, from freshly made dim sum to the famous seafood and stirfries. The diversity and richness of the flavors were amazing, and it felt like a true culinary adventure.

The atmosphere was buzzing with locals and tourists alike, all enjoying the lively street scenes. Traditional Chinese lanterns lit up the streets, adding a touch of cultural charm. What really stood out to me was how welcoming and safe it felt, even amidst the crowd. The energy was positive, and you could feel the blend of Thai and Chinese cultures in every cornerfrom the food to the temples and the local vendors.

Yaowarat is a mustvisit if youre in Bangkok, especially in the evening when the streets come to life. Whether youre here for food, shopping, or just to soak in the atmosphere, its an unforgettable experience. Highly recommend spending a few hours hereyou wont regret it! Chinatown is a mustvisit while being in Bangkok. It was raining when we were there but it couldn't stop people from flooding the area. The main street of Yaowarat was full of local food vendors. A bit more expensive than usual but worth to try. Everything was delicious!!!

리뷰:
Excellent museum for children and young teenagers. The processes of minting money and basic economics are covered. Adults may also enjoy the museum. Unfortunately, some of the machines used for learning were not working when I visited. June 2023 One of the best small and stylish community living museum, ever. As far as we know they are governmentrun but services are impeccable packed with most welcoming and utmost knowledgable staff.

Highly recommended. Bang Lamphu Museum is located on Phra Sumen Road, and is walkable from Phra Artit Road.

The museum is quite local but surprising, the space seems to be one of my favorite museum in Thailand. Ticket price for docent to give us a 1 hour tour is only 30 Baht. The tour goes on every half an hour and each tour capacity is around 810 people at max.

Although the tour is based on Thai Language, the caption of some of the archaeological findsitems can be in English Description.

The museum shows us the fascinating story of Banglumphu old days where market selling and its district are what is known for. There's also history learning part on how land was developed from time to time and even how nickelcoin are crafted and used for from the old times.

An absolute wonderful museum that worth every penny. Some of the visitors if hisher family member lives around here during 40s50s will surely inspired by those "nostalgic feeling" from start to the end.

Still photos are permitted only. Nice museum which tells you history of Bangkok old town and the old Banglumphu area. They also provide guided tour with good English speaking guide. At the top floor, you can get a good panoramic view of Rama 8 suspension bridge and the old fort nearby. Highly recommend. Awesome little free museum telling stories of the city through its infrastructure! Such as khlongs, walls, forts, and gates. You will get the most value out of the place if you watch all the videos, almost all of them have an English option.

리뷰:
Great view. Worth  1080 B entry fee. Their staff is obviously very good and caring. It is a mustsee place when you come to Bangkok. I also felt that the entry fee was a reasonable rate. It is better to leave around 2 o'clock in the afternoon.  It's more convenient for people to take pictures in the evening. This has been far the best roof top that I have been to, u get 360 views around the city. Every body goes for the sunset, if u would like to get a good spot I suggest going about 23 hours before sunset. This place will get jammed packed with people, they also have a bar on the top for refreshments from water to alcohol. After the sunset it pretty much closes, u will probably spend 3045min trying to get back to the bottom since only so many can fit on the elevator. Totally worth it! Morning visit. Great view of the city. The outside area is just too hot to relax and enjoy it for long. The glass floor area is pretty small compared to similar attractions in other cities. If you've done a glass floor before, skip this one. Lots of seating outside with a little coffee shop. I bet it is quite enjoyable when it's cooler.  For me, I'd just as well go to a rooftop bar to enjoy a good view and drinks. There is a long line to purchase the tickets.
Sometimes the top floor is closed due to rain and lightning risk.
The view is stunning. Really worth the money.
To come out one has to go through a labyrinth of duty free like stores. Wow! This was worth every cent. The view was amazing, the staff were friendly and helpful. We got there early for a 5pm session and were allowed in, unfortunately during our sessions we got a heavy storm, but the staff were well organised, leaving us to stay up the top until the last minute as the rain hit. They then allowed us onto level 74 where we watched all the lights come on in the city. We loved every minute there!

리뷰:
Statue of King Rama III, located in Bangkok, is a significant monument that honors King Nangklao, also known as King Rama III, the third monarch of the Chakri Dynasty. This statue is a prominent feature in a public space and serves as a tribute to the kings contributions to Thailand's history.

Historical Significance King Rama III reigned from 1824 to 1851 and is remembered for his efforts to modernize Thailand during a period of significant change. His reign was marked by a focus on improving the countrys infrastructure, including the construction of important public works and the promotion of trade and commerce. The statue commemorates his achievements and his role in shaping the nations development during his time.

Design and Features The statue depicts King Rama III in a regal posture, adorned in traditional royal attire. The sculptural details reflect the kings status and the artistry of the period. The monument is set on a raised pedestal, often surrounded by wellmaintained landscaping that enhances its visibility and prominence. The design is both elegant and respectful, capturing the kings dignified presence.

Visitor Experience The Statue of King Rama III is situated in an open area, allowing visitors to view and appreciate the monument from various angles. The surrounding space is usually peaceful, providing a reflective environment for those interested in learning about Thai history. Informational plaques or signage nearby typically offer details about the kings reign and contributions, enriching the visitor experience.

Surrounding Area The statue is located in a historical part of Bangkok, where visitors can explore other landmarks and cultural sites. Its central location makes it accessible and provides an opportunity to connect with the city's rich heritage. Nearby areas may include parks, historical buildings, or bustling streets, offering a range of activities and attractions for visitors.

Accessibility and Facilities The statue is easily accessible by public transportation, including the BTS Skytrain and local buses. The surrounding area is generally wellmaintained, though facilities directly at the statue may be limited. Visitors may need to seek amenities such as restrooms or dining options in nearby areas.

Overall Impression The Statue of King Rama III stands as a fitting tribute to a significant historical figure in Thailands history. Its prominent location and dignified design offer visitors a chance to honor and learn about King Rama IIIs contributions to the country. The monuments integration into the historical fabric of Bangkok makes it a meaningful stop for those interested in exploring the rich heritage of the Chakri Dynasty and Thailands development. Very nice park like place. It is very clean and a lot of room the walk around. The large monument is pretty neat and they have some other buildings that looks like they are for public events. If possible give it a walk though. The Statue of King Rama III, or "Phra Borom Racha Nusorn" in Thai, stands as a majestic tribute to one of Thailand's revered monarchs. Situated in a prominent location, this imposing monument commands attention and reverence from all who pass by.

Crafted with meticulous attention to detail, the statue captures the dignified presence and regal stature of King Rama III, known for his contributions to Thai literature, culture, and diplomacy during his reign in the 19th century.

Surrounded by lush greenery and set against the backdrop of Bangkok's vibrant skyline, the Statue of King Rama III serves as a serene oasis amidst the bustling cityscape. Visitors can pay their respects to the revered monarch and reflect on his enduring legacy while admiring the artistry and craftsmanship of the monument.

Whether you're a history enthusiast, a culture buff, or simply seeking a moment of tranquility in the heart of Bangkok, a visit to the Statue of King Rama III offers a meaningful and memorable experience that celebrates Thailand's rich heritage and royal legacy. Nice garden and stunning statue of Thai King here. Idk the detail of this place just happened to came across this landmark after boating to Phanfa. King Rama III Memorial
The monument of King Rama III was built by the Fine Arts Department in 1990 near the Royal Reception Pavilion in front of Wat Ratchanatdaram. His bronze statue is seated on a throne. The surrounding area is decorated with beautiful plants, with the Royal Reception Pavilion and three minor pavilions known as Sala Rai nearby. There are three more most important landmarks of Bangkok very close to this monument namely Golden Mount Temple just across the road, Democracy Monument at about 300 meters and Loha Prasat Temple just adjacent. It is a beautiful place to visit, if one has time.

리뷰:
This is a small to medium sized park nearby Victory Monument, where you can relax and enjoy the flowers or come to exercise by taking advantage of the free exercise equipment, or bars for body weight exercises. There is also a path for walkingrunning. Personally I came here fairly often to relax while on holiday since it was close to my hotel. Worth checking out if you are in the area. For a fitness enthusiast, Santiphap Park  is an absolute gem in the middle of Bangkok. The parks jogging trails are perfect for a morning run or an evening jog, surrounded by nature that makes the workout feel refreshing. The paths are wellmaintained and provide a safe and scenic route, free from the distractions and dangers of city traffic. The exercise stations scattered around the park are ideal for those looking to incorporate strength training into their routine without needing a gym. These stations allow for a variety of exercises, from pullups to leg presses, making it easy to get a fullbody workout in a beautiful outdoor setting.

Besides the physical benefits, the park also offers a great community vibe that's motivating for any fitness amateur. You often see groups practicing yoga, tai chi, or even aerobics, which can be inspiring and encouraging. The atmosphere is friendly and supportive, making it a great place to meet likeminded individuals who share a passion for fitness. The sense of camaraderie and the shared goal of staying healthy and active create a positive environment that makes working out feel less like a chore and more like a rewarding part of your day. Plus, after a good workout, you can always find a quiet spot to cool down, stretch, and just enjoy the peace that the park offers. What a beautiful park! Very well maintained with outdoor gym facilities, kids playgound and a lot of benches to relax. Great for a run in the morning. Skinny rectangular park with a very rough running track and some old weights to exercise. There's tons of orchids everywhere and a few benches to sit Amazing manicured park, busy with early morning joggers and people using the exercise equipment.  Beautiful orchid flowers in massed displays.  Many wonderful community features, recycling plastic bottles bin and bottle wall, sharing library, great array of edible plants with labels in Thai and also English botanical names, excellent labelling and most appreciated.  Spot the wildlife, big monitor lizard, turtles, birds and squirrels

located at the lower sukhumvit area, it's a park i enjoy doing laps around from the early mornings to the later evenings. it has pretty much all that it needs to be a great public space, exercise machines, decently sized courts for basketball and volleyball, playground for childrens, and it even has a little skatepark. the contrast between the greenery and the modern high rises in it's surroundings really makes it a good sight to see while sitting down and chatting. what honestly really surprised me was how well maintained it is.. nothing grimy dispite being a public space. seems like the park goes through cleaning service in certain periods throughout the day. all and all, felt really clean like completely modern and the spaces are great for sitting down and meeting up. also a bonus, there are little entrances to the emsphere mall to the far right of the park which is very convenient for escaping the burning heat. Benchasiri Park, a tranquil oasis in bustling Bangkok, captivates visitors with its lush greenery, serene lake, and vibrant bougainvillea. Tucked away amidst modern skyscrapers, it offers a peaceful retreat for picnics, leisurely strolls, and moments of contemplation. A harmonious blend of nature and urbanity, truly a gem in the heart of the city. Active park enjoyed by the community at large, workers taking lunch breaks,  teenagers hanging out, fussball players, skateboarders doing their thing in designated areas in the park.   Sculptures dotted along the park walking area with hikers and joggers making the most of the weather and the public holiday. 29 July 2024 Very beautiful park just beside the Emsphere and Emporium. It has volleyball, takraw  basketball. Also have different exercise equipment. It has fountain show at the evening time at 7 PM. Benchasiri Park is a serene oasis situated in the bustling heart of Bangkok, conveniently located near the Phrom Phong BTS station and the newly opened EmSphere mall. This proximity makes it easily accessible for a quick escape into nature amidst the urban environment.

The park boasts a beautifully maintained landscape with a wide variety of plant species and a large pond that adds to the tranquil atmosphere. The ambiance of Benchasiri Park is peaceful and inviting, making it a perfect spot for relaxation and leisure activities. Visitors can enjoy the wellequipped playground, which makes the park especially popular among families with children. The playground is safe and provides a variety of equipment, suitable for children of different ages, ensuring they have a fun and engaging experience.

For those looking to enjoy a day out, the park also offers ample space for picnics and gatherings. Its clean and wellmaintained picnic areas are ideal for family outings or a quiet day with a book. Additionally, the park includes various fitness installations and a jogging track, catering to those who wish to exercise in a natural setting.

Benchasiri Park is not only a haven for relaxation and play but also hosts various cultural and festive events throughout the year, adding to its appeal as a community hub. It is open daily from 500 AM to 900 PM, providing ample time for visitors to enjoy its facilities.

Highly recommended for both locals and tourists, Benchasiri Park is a delightful retreat in Bangkok that offers something for everyone, whether you're looking for a place to unwind, a fun day out with the family, or a spot to enjoy outdoor activities.

리뷰:
Siam Amazing Park in Thailand is a perfect weekday getaway, offering endless activities to enjoy throughout the day. It's less crowded, allowing for a relaxed experience. The international lunch buffet offers a wide variety of delicious options, satisfying every palate. The water activities in the separate section add to the fun and make it a complete day of enjoyment for visitors of all ages.

Siam Amazing Park in Thailand is renowned for its thrilling roller coasters, including the adrenalinepumping Mega Coaster and the familyfriendly Junior Coaster, offering rides for all thrill levels. Apart from roller coasters, the park boasts a variety of attractions such as water slides, wave pools, and a large artificial beach, ensuring a day filled with excitement and adventure. Very nice amusement park and water park. Good for family with children but basically everyone can enjoy the park. I have been visiting here since childhood and it's always nice to go back and have a good time with friends and family. They have built many new buildings and attractions. I do hope the place will be full with visitors soon. Good one but many rides were closed not functioning. Roller coaster was the best, and slidewheel was good. Big disappointment is that giant drop, 3d theatre and many rides were closed.

Water rides were decent but not many options. The usual ones.

In swimming pool, they didnt turn of the Wave at all. Even after asked, the guard said it wont be turned on. We left early by 3pm dissapointed. Locker facilities were not bad. I recently visited Siam Amazing Park and wanted to share my experience, especially regarding the "Amazing Adventure" part of the park. Unfortunately, I found it to be quite a disappointment, particularly if you have kids between the heights of 100cm to 130cm. The park has extremely strict rules on the rides, some of which are very basic and not even that thrilling. As a protective parent, I understand the importance of ageappropriate rides, but the restrictions here seemed excessive. The Log Flume water ride was one of the few thrilling attractions where my kids could join me. However, the experience was marred by a considerable wait time. Although we were initially informed of a 30minute wait, it ended up taking an unexpected 1.5 hours. This delay was not due to long queues or a large crowd, but rather due to slow staff and the limited number of operating boats.

Due to these rules, my kids were left feeling bored, let down, and sad. They could only go on rides meant for infants and little kids, which didn't match their excitement levels. It's disheartening to see a park that is meant to provide fun and entertainment end up making kids feel excluded. I would advise not wasting your time here, as this park seems empty and lifeless for a reason.during a weekend.

Furthermore, I must mention that the staff at Siam Amazing Park weren't very friendly. Their lack of warmth and willingness to assist added to the overall disappointment of the visit. It's important to feel welcomed and valued as a guest, but unfortunately, that was not the case here.

Overall, I can say that my visit to Siam Amazing Park's adventure part was a letdown, particularly for families with kids in the 100cm to 130cm height range. The strict rules further limited the enjoyment. Considering the underwhelming experience and unfriendly staff, I would recommend exploring other options for a more enjoyable family outing. We went there on a weekday morning so there were barely any people but the rides were very fun. Didnt realize there was a huge wavepool in the park so its quite a pleasant surprise though I wish we brought swimming gear.

The buffet was cheap and the foods were okay.

Creating your own art pieces, bead bracelet or necklace and painting, in the charming old wooden house by the canals. Its a good place to escape from the hectic life in Bangkok. The vibe couldnt be better. Staffs are friendly. Recommend to visit in the morning before the place gets crowded. Dont miss a chance to try Thai tea latte from the cafe. It is a great place for sightseeing with lovely surroundings and many choices of food and snacks. This place offers a variety of art and crafts if you are looking for a place to spend the day in Bangkok.  It is definitely recommended

주소: 161, 163 Thanon Khao San, Khwaeng Talat Yot, Khet Phra Nakhon, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon 10200, Thailand
리뷰:
If youre in Bangkok, Khaosan Market is a mustvisit destination. Its a vibrant, partyfilled atmosphere where you can find just about anythingweed, crocodile belly meat, scorpions and other insects to snack on, tattoo parlors, massage parlors, clubs, pubs, and endless street food.

The crowd is awesome, full of energy, and the overall vibe is unmatched. If you have a cool mindset and enjoy a lively atmosphere, this place is for you. But if you cant handle the intensity, its best to steer clear. This is the party central of Bangkok. We went to a pub called Khao San Central which is in the middle of the walking street. Love the energy and vibe of this place. The pricing is so damn good you wont feel like leaving. We went twice to the same pub. You can sit eat and dance. It is a very good market place as well you can come with friends and drink and enjoy it here. All night open this market. Whenever I am in this place I feel alive.

You can sit eat and dance. It is a very good market place as well you can come with friends and drink and enjoy it here. All night open this market. Whenever I am in this place I feel alive. Plenty of street foods to choose from.
Night life is also just next to each other. Loud music and plenty of people.
Waiters are standing and waiting for customers, some will even touch you and convince you to sit in their bar.
Definitely for those party enthusiasts.
Many drunkards tourists walking around and dancing.

There is also a street that is more calm and mostly for those who just wants to chill and relax.
Plenty of options.
Recommended just for experience. I enjoyed the market, however, I believe that the shops were pretty repetitive when it comes to food however, it was not as crowded as Chinatown and thats a big plus! The food we had was really good.

It would be great if event curators could be brought in and turn this place into an arts and cultural hub. 리뷰:
This Building is the Buddhist library, called Phra Mondop in Thai. It was built during the reign of King Rama I in 1789 for containing a large beautiful motherofpearl inlay book cabinet to house the Buddhist scripture. Each ornate building in Grand Palace Bangkok competes for attention, however I feel the Phra Mondop is the most beautiful of all of them. Beautiful pillared library in square layout with pointed pyramid shaped roof.
Mostly in gold colour with multicoloured entricate designs all around.
It is a part of Grand Palace complex and can be accesses with the same entrance ticket. May not be allowed to enter but the shape, colour and fine designs mesmerizes you from any angle. Part of The Grand Palace never open to the public. There is a stone Buddha at each corner. Next prah Mondop or the library was constructed by  king rama the first which houses Buddhist scriptures.
It always closed to the public.
The cabinet  made from the mather of peal, if you eant to see picture, please buy a temple book.
If is useful, please hit LIKE button. Thank you Phra Mondop

리뷰:
It is a small art concept park under the bridge. You can slowly appreciate the painting and sit in the shade under the bridge and enjoy the Chao Phraya River to your heart's content. Your mind will be at peace. Good experience to see artworks of Nonthaburi depicting life is changing.  You spend 2030 minutes here to enjoy the art works and river view. Parking lots are available until 1900 everyday. Foods  drinks are available near by. What a great idea to have invited artist to paint those rather blank walls. Wish the experience could be replicated in other cities. Deserves a good 5star rating... There are many pictures of street art, come early in the morning.
Or in the evening would be better. We arrived at approx.
1830 Many lights are broken and not very bright.
The resulting picture is therefore quite dark. But there are still people who come lively.
Both jogging and fishing. Street ArtNonthaburi It is another landmark of Nonthaburi Province. Located under Maha Jesada Bodin Bridge. Close to the Old City Pillar Shrine, Nonthaburi Province.

It is a threedimensional street art that draws colorful pictures. Reflecting the story of the identity of Nonthaburi Province. Whether it is the way of life of the community, traditions, culture, good things of Nonthaburi. It is conveyed through street art images both on the walls and around the bridge piers.

Street art paintingsNonthaburi There is much to admire, such as the provincial motto. Somdej Phra Srinagarindra Park Nonthaburi City Hall old house, floating market, tricycles, durian, local games Waterside lifestyle, etc.

Street ArtNonthaburi is open for free viewing every day from 600 a.m.  730 p.m.

주소: 322 Tri Mit Rd, Khwaeng Talat Noi, Khet Samphanthawong, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon 10100, Thailand
리뷰:
To avoid the weekend crowd, go during the weekdays. You'll never go hungry in Chinatown and there's so many stalls with different offerings. This place is a mustsee and visit when you're in Bangkok. Chinatown bangkok is the largest chinatown of the world. To kick start your visit, it would be great to start of right at the chinatown gate!

Definitely photo worthly. One of the historical sites in China Town, Yaowarat Road. It's located near the old temple of the Golden Buddha statue. Very beautiful, free to visit. Walking along the road to other attractive sites is very nice. It's crowded and hectic, but it's interesting. But why does it feel more like Taiwan than the streets of China? Some streets even felt similar to Kaosan Road. There is no single safety personnel who control the streets, so I think it's right to have an onsite patrol agent if it's a place where tourists visit so much. Must visit and have meal there. The crowded main is walkable distance. Easy to get Grab at the junction near 711.

주소: 333 Chak Phra Rd, Khwaeng Khlong Chak Phra, Khet Taling Chan, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon 10170, Thailand
리뷰:
Fun little floating market !!! Not too touristy like the popular ones. Food, drink and mechadises are fantastic here. Boat ride of 1 hour ans 20 minutes tour is 500 bahts 14, 13 Euros, 19,000 wons. Taxi ride from Democracy Monument was 100 bahts 3 or maybe take Tuk Tuk 120150 bahts, which is more fun to get to the market. Stroll around and see what it is like to love like the local villagers and market people go about their lives. Get a hair cut while you enter the floating market !!! Totally, worth a visit. It was very fun experience  We went on a rainy day, and it's not a good idea 
The market is rather commercial, I don't feel localmarketvibe... foods and stuff are things you can find anywhere. The food stalls by the canal are not ideal either. The stalls are located along the canal, while the seating is in the middle. It looks packed and uncomfortable, so we didn't eat anything here. Anyway the people were so nice  Vibes are really good , locals selling mango sticky rice, family of musicians playing traditional thai music, children feed fishes  , peaceful atmosphere other than the occasional train rumble. Beware of the tour guides pretending to sell floating market tickets , its a scam! The floating market is that place itself One of floating market in Bangkok, Taling Chan Floating Market. Though it is quite small, but there are plenty of food and Thai dessert. You can enjoy casual eating area along the cannel where you can order varieties of grilled seafood with seasonal prices. If you have time, you can do some excursion by renting private boat charter for 1.20 hour. Even though it's called a market, there are no shops selling anything, and it doesn't feel like a market. It's just a boat ride down a dirty river. There's a 20minute break on the way, and we only eat at the ground market.

이름: Liverpool Graffiti Art ซอยเจริญกรุง 33
주소: PGM7+7WG, Soi Luean Rit 1, Khwaeng Talat Noi, Khet Samphanthawong, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon 10100, Thailand
리뷰: "Liverpool Graffiti Art, Soi Charoen Krung 33" is a mesmerizing showcase of urban creativity in the heart of Bangkok. Nestled in the vibrant neighborhood of Charoen Krung, this hidden gem features an impressive array of colorful and thoughtprovoking street art. From vibrant murals depicting local culture to abstract pieces that challenge the imagination, each artwork tells a unique story and adds character to the bustling streetscape. Exploring this graffiti art scene is like embarking on a visual journey through Liverpool's cultural tapestry, with every corner offering a new discovery. Whether you're a seasoned art enthusiast or simply a curious passerby, a visit to Liverpool Graffiti Art promises an immersive and memorable experience in the vibrant streets of Bangkok. Loved the place! Super tasty, staff is very friendly, talked us through indian culture and stuff. Will certainly be back! Art on wall Well, that wasn't worth the journey. The only painting left us this one. The other picture has been graffitied over. Maybe by a bitter Everton fan.  Unless you're down that way, I wouldn't bother going. There is a beautiful temple just around the corner though. It can be said that the graffiti has been covered, and the grilled bananas on the roadside seemed very good, but unfortunately I was not hungry and did not try it.

주소: 80 1 Thanon Arun Amarin, Khwaeng Arun Amarin, Khet Bangkok Noi, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon 10700, Thailand
리뷰:
Location is not strategic, the path leads you to a long winding road. If you happen to take a Grab it will not drop you at the exact location. You will need to follow the sign and walk for a distance with small passageway to the exact spot. Just dont get lost!

200 Baht per entry We took a boat and got down at the nearest pier and walkes around 950 meters to reach this place.  It was all small alleys and the people were doing their daily stuff.  It is an interesting walk and since Thai people are very nice, it is safe to walk in those alleys it is an experience, alleys are probably 4 to 6 ft  wide.

Once we reached this place, it is amazing. Not a very big museum with lots of displays.  But worth visiting.  If you take a private boat ride, then there is a stop here on the front side of it.

Very large boats used by royals, in good condition after a king restored it.

Restrooms are there and very clean. Very beautiful, ornately carved, boats dating back many years.  Only 100 BHT less than 3 US dollars  The walk to the museum was the highlight as you walk down narrow walkways past homes, stalls and shops next to a canal.  Just outside the museum is a sweet older man offering boat rides, beer and water.  He has an adorable bird that sings and puffs up right in front of his shop. Beautiful as always. You shouldn't miss a visit to the Royal Barges Nacional Museum. I come every time a visit Thailand. National Museum Of Royal Barges.

Address
801 Arun Ammarin Road Bangkok Noi, Bangkok

The Royal Barge Procession is one of the most spectacular events in the world. It is performed occasionally during the Tod Kathin Buddhist Festival when H.M. The King delivers new robes to the monks at Wat Arun. It was also seen by millions of viewers around the world when it was specially staged for the 2003 APEC Conference in Bangkok and broadcast live to the participating countries. These ornately decorated boats are maintained by the Royal Thai Navy and docked at The Royal Barge National Museum on Bangkok Noi canal on the Thonburi side. The most impressive and important boat is the Kings personal barge, Suphanahong which was built in 1911. It is 46 metres in length hewn from a single tree and covered with intricate gilt carvings and colourful pieces of glass. The design is representative of a mythical swan. The crew consists of 54 oarsmen who paddle in time to the rhythmic beat of a drummer. The Royal Barge fleet consists of 52 vessels. Each is a masterpiece of marine and traditional craftsmanship. They feature a variety of figureheads on their bows, including a sacred Garuda, Hanuman and the seven heads of Naga. Information the fleet travels in rows five abreast and more than one kilometer from the leading barge to those at the rear. These are propelled by 2,082 specially trained naval personnel. A visit to The Royal Barge National Museum will give you an insight into the colourful culture of Thailand.

One of the most beautiful ceremony you will ever see floating in the river is The Royal Barge Procession which amazing royal barges glide along Chao Phraya river. Each barge is taken care of very carefully by the Fine Arts Department under supervision of the Bureau of the Royal Household and royal navy. In normal days, the royal barges are kept in National Museum of Royal Barges. The National Museum of Royal Barges in Bangkok is a former royal cradle for royal barges. The Fine Arts department registered every barge as national heritage and appointed the cradle to National Museum of Royal Barges Bangkok in 1974. Antiques in the National Museum of Royal Barges 1. The Suphannahong Royal Barge. The barge figurehead was crafted to swan shape. This is a supreme barge where the king sits during the procession. The Suphannahong Royal Barge was built in King Chulalongkorn and finished in the reign of King Rama 6. 2. The Narai Song Suban HM Rama 9 Royal Barge. The Fine Arts department in collaboration with The Royal Navy and the Bureau of the Royal Household built this barge especially for King Bhumibol Adulyadej. 3. The Anantanakkharat Royal Barge. The barge figurehead was crafted to nagashape with 7heads. This is also the supreme barge which was built in the reign of Rama VI for carrying important Bhuddha images or robes for presentation to the monks at the end of Buddhist Lent in The Royal Barge Procession. 4. The Anekchat Puchong Royal Barge. The figurehead was crafted to small many nagashape. This barge is a reserved barge which was built in the reign of King Rama V. 5. The Asurawayupak Royal Barge. The figurehead is a monster with a body of indigo bird. 6. The Karbi Prab Maung Marn Royal Barge. The figurehead was crafted to a swordsman shape. 7. The Krut Hern Hej Royal Barge. The figurehead was crafted to garudashape. 8. Akkachai Hern Haw Royal Barge. The figurehead was decorated with crocodile paintings. Transportation 1. By boatTake a tourist boat provided by boat services or local boats for rent 2. By landUse a road near Arun Amarin bridge or Phra Pinklao bridge on Thonburi side of Chaophraya river, close to Dusitaram temple to the destination. Operating days MondaySunday Operating hours 900 am500 pm. Contact information Address 801 Arun Amarin Road, Bangkok Noi, Bangkok

이름: Wat Maha That Yuwarat Rangsarit Ratchaworamahawihan
주소: 3, 5 Maha Rat Road, Khwaeng Phra Borom Maha Ratchawang, Khet Phra Nakhon, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon 10200, Thailand
리뷰:
One of the most important temples around the Grand Palace in Bangkok is worth a visit. Beautiful temple spaces and grounds, but I was here trying to find the free daily meditation course, and ended up leaving after 45 min of searching. Even after finally finding the building note SECTION 5, not BUILDING 5 on map, I was there before and after 200 and there was no course. It would be helpful if the location  schedule was more clearly described onlineonsite, as I imagine this is a draw for many confused tourists like myself and I was sad to miss it This is a very unique place that you cant miss in Bangkok if you want some quiet time for reflection and planning. A royal temple close to the Grand Palace, it has magnificent Buddhism building and statues, but very few tourists or local people will visit it. Do try to spend an hour or so in front on the Buddha, putting aside your electronics and enjoy talking to yourself, where you are from and heading for next. Peaceful monastery and cute cats
We can make an offering of food to the monks The international meditation centre has extremely kind and helpful people who were glad to take us in with open arms and provided a personal class for me and my friend. They also provided us with advice for staying safe in Bangkok. We greatly appreciate the time and knowledge they provided for us.

The international meditation centre is hard to find, however.

리뷰:
Admission is free.  Need to take off your shoes. This is a high leg tiny wooden house. Showcasing the history of old times. The guide will show you around the house. Good to visit. A small museum about this part of Bangkok situated in a beautiful old wooden building. Most of the explanations are written only in Thai, though. But, if you speak a little Thai, the extremely friendly caretaker will personally give you a tour of all exhibits... No English Language anywhere. Also Thia writing is left to write with no spaces or punctuation. So Phranakhondistrict.

This is a district museum  is the one of Phra Nakhon district, the central district of Bangkok. Prior to its merger with Thonburi, the Bangkok province was named Phra Nakhon after this central district. The museum is located directly next to the district office on Samsen road. It is therefore close to the popular tourist area of Khao San road.

The museum is in a wooden house in traditional Thai style, the former residence of Phraya Borirak Ratcha , who was a palace guard for King Rama V till Rama VII. In one room in the second floor it has some portrait paintings of the former homeowner.

The other rooms show various exhibits connected with the local history, the traditions of the citizen like local products, like the baskets and other wickerwork as shown in the photo. Worth calling in if you're passing to see a well constructed original Bangkok house. Free entry. Worth visiting, nice heritage place.

주소: 296/1 Sukhumvit Rd, Tambon Bang Pu Mai, Amphoe Mueang Samut Prakan, Chang Wat Samut Prakan 10280, Thailand
리뷰:
My partner and I visited on a Monday. Starting from Siam, we took a 45minute train ride followed by a 10minute taxi ride to reach the destination.

The place is expansive, so I highly recommend bringing essentials like an umbrella, water, sunglasses, and an extra shirt as it can get quite humid. They offer a tram service and bikes for getting around, or you can rent a golf cart for more convenience. The tram makes stops at the four major locations, which is more than enough to cover the key sights. We spent about two hours exploring and found it to be a pleasant and efficient way to see everything. Ancient City is a fantastic spot for photography enthusiasts, with many picturesque replicas of Thailands most famous landmarks. Its not as crowded as some of the more popular tourist spots, making it perfect for a peaceful exploration and photo sessions.

One tip for budgetconscious travelers is to buy tickets online, as they tend to be much cheaper compared to buying them at the entrance. However, be prepared for additional charges. The park is quite large, so unless you plan to walk for hours, youll likely need to rent a golf cart, which is an extra cost. Also, some activities and exhibits within the park require separate payments.

Overall, its a great place to immerse yourself in Thailand's culture and history, but it's important to plan for extra expenses beyond the entrance fee. This place is very huge, no exaggeration! Definitely have to rent a golf cart if you want to visit all the sites. For 2 people seats, 350 baht for the first hour, and 100 baht for every next hour. I spent 5 hours in this place using a golf cart, now imagine how long you spend your time without one. My ticket includes a buffet where you can go inside this place. Overall, this place is wonderful, there are a lot of great buildingstemples. Worth every penny. Beautiful place worth every penny. You can roam around the place the whole day and explore the Thai history. Place very instagramable. I would recommend you rent a golf cart specially when the weather is hot. Bicycle is provided free with your entrance ticket. The only problem was the choice of food, it was really limited. Ancient City, located near Bangkok, is a vast outdoor museum with replicas of Thailand's historical landmarks and cultural sites. Its my favorite place for photography even though it can be quite hot outside, the stunning architecture makes the effort worthwhile. The park is huge, so you can spend a whole day exploring. There are also Thai restaurants onsite serving a range of traditional dishes.

리뷰:
Beautiful architecture combining traditional Thai elements with Khmer  Gothic influences. The building was the royal crematorium of Maha Vajirunhis, the Crown Prince  eldest son of King Rama V, before it was turned into a library. Today, it functions as a museum portraying the life  royal duties of King Rama V. Admission free, Wednesdays to Sundays, 9.30am  4pm. A surprising museum that holds its own against all the other competing spots in the area. But, it is much smaller and the exhibits were limited to two subjects only at the time of my visit. None the less, I was well received  no entrance fees and a beautifully curated exhibit of Cabinets dating back to various points in Thai history was on display.  If you enjoy slow travel and museums that show something different, you might just enjoy this. Free museum! They have a huge collection of cabinets from various eras. There's also the exhibit dedicated to King Chulalongkorn. A perfect for Museum adventurer.
Just a walking distance around the Kings Palace. This place is iconic for its usual stunning Red shadeEarthly themed structure which houses glimpse of histories important documents and memorabilia.
and it is Free The long, narrow building paint in barn red next to the grand palace is now fully restored and display the Beautiful selection of master of Saim Gold gilding art Lai Rod Nham on cabinets. The painting shows the royal and local lifestyle of the Ayuthaya period 17th century. Include the mythology and nature with such a fine detail.

이름: Photo spot for the Big Buddha at Paknam Temple (Phra Buddha Dhammakaya Thep Mongkol)
주소: 838 Thanon Thoet Thai, Khwaeng Talat Phlu, Khet Thon Buri, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon 10600, Thailand
리뷰:
Perfect spot to take photos with a better perspective of the temple and the Buddha. Its not hard to get to, just less than 10 minutes from the temple. Its at the end of a kind of hidden alleyway just follow Google Maps directionsthey are pretty accurate. I went a bit late, so the light wasnt the best. On the right side of the canal, you can see the sunset. The best time to visit this place is at golden hours to sunset, avoid noon time as it's very hot. You can rent a small boat to go around the river and take photos 200bathperson which is good experience in Bangkok. There is more ppl at this spot on weekend but the queue is not long tho. It's totally free to take photo here. Free admission to this photospot. Just across the river. Sadly, renovations are ongoing. Boat service available at 200bahtperson, mainly for phototaking.

To get here, just follow Google maps. You will cross a very steep bridge and walk around 10mins from Wat Paknam. There are signages around the area clearly displayed. This place looks like a backyard of their residential area. It's hard to go inside the street with your own car since the lane are very narrow. And the boat service is a little bit expensive which is around 200 Baht person. This spot is great to get a photo with some building and with the giant Buddha to get a perspective of the size of the statue. Also, there is a small boat service that operates there where it can take you around the water area for roughly 30minutes. It is a more interesting way to go to the temple and they will slow down in areas to let you get your photos and videos. You can ask to return to the original spot or you can be dropped off at the giant Buddha pier entrance.

Fantastic. One of the best curated exhibitions Ive seen in a long time.
It was very interactive. The princess clothing was super and exhibited really well. There is a senior citizens discount which was 80 bahts. This exhibition was on the second floor and photographs were not allowed so the images were taken from the catalog. On the first floor is an amazing exhibition of weaving and design. I was truly inspired by everything I saw. I really appreciate the culture and art of the country. I love fashion, I am interested in fabrics, I am interested in production and design. I really liked the museum. Thank you for such an opportunity to touch this experience. The building is air conditioned and walking in just makes you feel nice after walking under the sun. There was a man standing at the entrance of the building who asked to see the ticket. After I showed it to him, I put it back in my pocket. Unfortunately then I met a woman at the podium inside who also asked to see the ticket. It took me a few seconds to show her my ticket but her tone was rude as I was looking for the ticket.  I suggest they can just put up a sign that tells people to prepare their ticket. Beautiful dresses during the finest era. Her Majesty Queen Sirikits Wardrobe Created by Pierre Balmain were made so exquisitely beautiful. You cant take any photos when inside. You should not miss this on your way out of Grand Palace. Dont forget to collect textile stamps representing their citystate before you leave. batik collection is no longer there the exhibition focuses on clothing work by the queen and then the princess cant take photos of the clothes. you can buy a ticket onsite for just this museum if you dont want to go to the palace 150bht.

there are a few interactive activities and the museum explains about what makes fabric different across thailand. very good.

Take a real long exposure of several minutes to let the water be smooth and all boats are faded out. Good luck.

We always found somewhere to sit, but I could tell it might be a different story if it were any busier. I loved the murals along the walk. There's always something cool to see during your walk. I'll definitely go back and maybe check out the secondfloor bar next time.

주소: 1871 Thanon Rama IV, Khwaeng Pathum Wan, Pathum Wan, Krung Thep Maha Nakhon 10330, Thailand
리뷰:
The Snake Farm Bangkok

The Snake Farm at the Queen Saovabha Memorial Institute QSMI in Bangkok, Thailand, is a unique and educational attraction that combines research, conservation, and public education on venomous snakes.

Venom extraction happens at 11.00
Snake show and photo opportunity is at 14.00
You can leave, get some lunch and reenter on the same ticket.

Toilets are available and well cared for.

History and Purpose

The Queen Saovabha Memorial Institute was established in 1913 as the Pastura Institute, initially focused on manufacturing and distributing rabies vaccine. It was later renamed the Pasteur Institute and eventually the Queen Saovabha Memorial Institute in honor of Queen Saovabha Phongsri, the mother of King Rama VI. The snake farm was added in the early 1920s, making it the second such facility in the world after the Instituto Butantan in So Paulo, Brazil.

Activities and Exhibits

 Venom Extraction and Handling Shows Visitors can observe live venom extraction sessions and snake handling shows, which are conducted at specific times during the week. These shows include interactions with various species, such as king cobras, Malayan kraits, and Russells vipers.
 Museum and Lectures The institute features a museum with exhibits on snake evolution, anatomy, toxicology, and reproduction. Lectures are given by doctors and handlers, providing detailed information about snakes and their habits.
 Snake Enclosures The farm houses thousands of snakes from over 35 species, including some of the most venomous snakes in the world. Visitors can view these snakes in wellmaintained vivariums.

Educational and Conservation Efforts

The QSMI is committed to protecting and breeding endangered snakes and educating the public about snakes. The institute regularly welcomes school groups to educate children about venomous and nonvenomous snakes and what to do in case of a snake bite.

Location and Accessibility

The Queen Saovabha Memorial Institute is located at the intersection of Rama IV and Henri Dunant Roads, next to Chulalongkorn Hospital and University. It is approximately 800 meters northwest of the Sala Daeng BTS Skytrain and Silom MRT Stations.

Operating Hours

The snake farm is open Monday through Friday from 930 AM to 330 PM and on weekends from 930 AM to 100 PM

Admission and Experience

The entry fee is modest, around 200 Baht approximately 7, making it an affordable and educational experience. Visitors can participate in snake handling sessions, though there have been some concerns raised about the handling practices, with some reviews suggesting that snakes might be treated with care but also potentially drugged for interactions.

The Snake Farm at the Queen Saovabha Memorial Institute is a significant center for snake research, antivenom production, and public education, offering a unique and informative experience for visitors Wonderful place. There have a lot of snake and have 2 type of show
1. Venom extraction show 11.00 am
2. Snake handling show 14.00 pm As a foreigner. I pay 5 times more. Although when asking can get a small discount. Other than that, very informative with a lot of lical snakes to observe. The show is also interesting with the option to hold a python good to overcome fear of snakes. Recommended i go to this place in public holidays so the fee exempt.
the show will start 1100am in weekend.
and 1430am in normal day.

Thonburi Palace is mostly closed for public as it now serves as the headquarter of Thailand's Navy headquarters. However, during special days such as its anniversary, it would be open to public for a short period. While taking pictures is prohibited within the buildings, visitors are allowed to take pictures outside the buildings. We learn how King Taksin fight for Siamese independence from the Burnese who sacked the capital city of Ayuthya and burnt everything to the ground. Also we see how the royalty in the early years of the independence lived.

이름: Sri Nakhon Khuean Khan Park and Botanical Garden
주소: 73 Soi Wat Rat Rangsan, Tambon Bang Kachao, Amphoe Phra Pradaeng, Chang Wat Samut Prakan 10130, Thailand
리뷰:
A perfect park for those who want an escape from the bustling city center. It was nice to bike around the park, although the roads were pretty bumpy because of the tree roots.
You got to make sure you find the right entrance to the parktheres a main gate close to the deck, otherwise youll end up challenging yourself on a weird path that looks exactly Temple Run to get into the park. Sri Nakhon Khuean Khan Park and Botanical Garden   is a large green space located in the Bang Krachao area of Phra Pradaeng, often referred to as the "Green Lung" of Bangkok. It offers a peaceful escape from the city's bustling environment, providing visitors with a serene and natural atmosphere. The park is known for its lush greenery, cycling paths, and walkways, which wind through forests, ponds, and gardens.

This botanical garden showcases a wide variety of native plants and trees, making it an excellent spot for nature lovers and birdwatchers. In addition to walking and cycling, visitors can enjoy picnicking, relaxing by the ponds, or simply soaking in the peaceful surroundings.

Sri Nakhon Khuean Khan Park is popular with both locals and tourists looking for outdoor activities in Bangkok. The area is also famous for its ecotourism and is accessible by boat or road, with many people visiting as part of a day trip to the nearby Bang Krachao area.

..Chat.G.P.T.. Sri Nakhon Khuean Khan Park and Botanical Garden

Sri Nakhon Khuean Khan Park and Botanical Garden is a hidden gem for nature lovers. This place is perfect for anyone looking to escape the city's hustle and immerse themselves in a lush, green environment. The park is filled with dense forests and a variety of plant species, making it an ideal spot for a leisurely walk or bike ride.

There are plenty of trails to explore, and you can even find a few quiet spots to relax and take in the serene atmosphere. The watchtower offers a great vantage point to enjoy a panoramic view of the surrounding greenery.

Overall, it's a fantastic location for a peaceful day out, especially if you're interested in botanic diversity and enjoy being surrounded by nature. Highly recommended for a slow, relaxing day! So much fun renting a bike! A great way to explore this huge park in the green lung.

Many trails, bridges, restaurants and Coffe shops to explore. I really enjoyed walking through that garden. It is astonishing to be in the middle of Bangkok and still feel like being miles away. You can feed the fish and have a drink whilst doing it which you can buy near the pond.

Really quiet and beautiful place with only requirement to enter  filling out a google form.
On the con side  all the information signs are in Thai and to be honest it would be nice to have information on butterflies in English. Beautiful and free to visit! None of the exhibits are in English so I went straight to the garden part. Small a 30 minute leisurely stroll through it but abundant colorful butterflies and beautiful flora. Definitely recommend if you are nearby! I had a wonderful time visiting this beautiful garden. It's filled with a variety of butterflies that add to the charm of the place. The garden is wellmaintained, and the scent of flowers is everywhere, making it a delightful experience. It's a very pleasant place to spend time in. I highly recommend everyone to visit this butterfly garden. I loved it, but you have to access it from within the park, whereas Google Maps suggests you can from road through a fence.

Takes about 30 mins maximum but it's free and you'll get some nice photos! The covered butterfly has no or very small quantity of butterflies.

Its a free entry area perfect for tourists however theres not much of butterflies on a Butterfly Garden.

The surrounding area is great, filled with trees, different kinds of plants and flowers that were well taken care of.
A perfect place for cardio exercises such as walking, jogging, running and bicycle.

리뷰:
That is ok to visit here once The architecture has local characteristics, the place is very empty, and then its really hot and the sun is really strong, so you need to do a good job in the sun. I went there in a hurry around 3 o'clock.
I was worried about whether I would be able to get in since it closed relatively early, but I was glad that I was able to watch the changing of the guard ceremony just as I left. The ticket price for foreigners is 500 baht per person. There is a special passage for Thais on the far left side of the entrance. When no Thais pass through, the staff will instruct foreigners queuing next to use the special passage for Thais. However, the staff sitting before scanning the QR code on the ticket at the entrance actually reached out to pick at the tourists with a very bored expression. Having lived in Thailand for nearly 6 years, I was very surprised and angry. This kind of behavior is too rare in Thailand. I have no interest in visiting, eating, drinking or shopping in Bangkok. Such staff should not be present in the famous and touristy Grand Palace. The king came unexpectedly, so it was closed and there was no way to go in without any notice.
